awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Testing the gravitational inverse square law and weak equivalence principle
awd_abstract_narration:
A primary goal of modern physics is to understand at the most fundamental level possible the nature and behavior of matter and energy. Empirical tests of Einstein's weak-field (Newtonian) gravity play an important role in judging possible extensions of this understanding. Even small deviations from Newtonian behavior could provide new clues to a more general formulation of the so-called Standard Model of fundamental interactions a "holy grail" of modern physics. Such deviations have not yet been detected, but the possibilities for expecting such anomalies at a low level abound in the theoretical literature over the past decade. The goal of this project is to carry out two experiments that will substantially restrict the viability of these theoretical speculations by setting at least an order-of-magnitude more stringent empirical upper limit on the strength of putative non-Newtonian behavior than already established. Alternatively, these more-precise measurements could uncover previously undetected deviations. Either outcome would advance our fundamental understanding of the physical fabric of our universe.
This collaboration between research groups at the University of Washington and the University of California Irvine exploits new advances in measurement precision using cryogenic techniques, new methods dramatically to reduce systematic effects, and a unique laboratory facility that provides an ultra-low vibration environment.  Moreover, these activities involve young scientists (post-docs, graduate and undergraduate students) as well as corporate partner Boeing Airplane Company and institutional sponsor Pacific Northwest National Laboratory.

por.por_cntn:
Einstein’s 1915 General Theory of Relativity has undergone many stringent tests and so far survived as the best theory of gravitation we have, even though more than a century has passed since its introduction.  A spectacular recent test is the discovery of gravitational radiation from the violent coalescence of pairs of “extremely compact” celestial objects, Black Holes and Neutron Stars, as predicted from Einstein’s equations — a phenomenon associated with extraordinarily strong gravity under highly relativistic conditions.  Our project, by contrast, is a test operating in the non-relativistic, weak-field limit, and could play an important role in judging theory-driven extensions of the physics community’s Standard Model of fundamental interactions. 

Consider the following analogy to the nature of our project.  Guided by Galileo's work and his own experiments, Isaac Newton formulated a theory of gravity in which the force of attraction between two bodies is independent of their composition and proportional to the inertia (mass) of each, thereby transparently satisfying Galileo's empirically informed conjecture regarding the Universality of Free Fall (the apocryphal experiment of simultaneously unequal-mass iron balls falling from the tower of Pisa with the same acceleration and consequently hitting the ground simultaneously).  

Similarly, Einstein honored the manifest success of Newton’s theory by assuring that his own equations match predictions of the Newtonian formalism under “classical” (non-relativistic, weak-gravity) conditions found in an ordinary terrestrial environment.   In both cases, the reasoning implicitly raises supposition to the lofty status of principle.  A “supposition” in the sense that Newton assumed Galileo’s hypothesis to be correct, and that Einstein assumed the validity of Newton’s theory.  What if, at some low level (so low that not yet detected), Newtonian gravity does not accurately describe the physical interaction between uncharged, unmagnetized, macroscopic bits of ordinary matter in the classical-conditions limit? 

So, what if the historically pivotal Newtonian synthesis were wrong in finest detail?  Measuring any significant deviation from Newtonian behavior, no matter how small, could provide new insights to the nature of gravitation and reveal new fundamental physics.  Because physics is an empirical science, this question constitutes sufficient merit and motivation for us to attempt an ultra-high-precision measurement to pursue evidence that could rule out Einstein's assumption.  Recall that science is advanced through disproof of hypotheses; “scientific proof” is an oxymoron.  A fundamental aspect of Newton’s formulation of the gravitation force between two masses is that it varies inversely as the square of the distance separating them; accordingly, we have conducted an experimental search of unprecedented sensitivity for Inverse-Square-Law Violation (ISLV). 

Our tentative result at this time is an upper limit on the statistical uncertainty in our detection/measurement of ISLV:  that this uncertainty in measured strength of violation is less than roughly 0.005% of the strength of Newtonian gravity (only 1 part in 20,000).  This high statistical precision suggests the possibility of setting a new, substantially lower limit on the measured magnitude of ISLV, but such an outcome depends on the quantitative bounds placed on experimental bias possible in these data, and on the central issue of the empirically determined magnitude for the ISLV signal, as explained below:

1) We have the statistical analysis of our data essentially in hand, but are still engaged in examining possible sources of experimental bias, effects (mechanical, electronic, magnetic, gravitational, or thermal) that could mimic the specific character of the ISLV “signal” that we seek to detect.  Such sources of false signal (i.e. signal bias) are difficult to diagnose, because they depend on the details of experiment design choices.  Note the reminder in the caption of the attached Figure 3, that this project is intentionally constructed as a "null experiment;" that is, the effects of ordinary (Newtonian) gravity are strongly suppressed by design.  Hence, any significant "signal" detected (i.e. significantly exceeding its measurement uncertainly) is considered indicative of ISLV.

2) Our data analysis is rigorously conducted as a “blind” exercise.  In analysis computations, any quantitative measure of an ISLV signal is masked from view.  This precaution precludes “fiddling” with data processing, unconsciously to favor a particular empirical outcome.  The data must speak for themselves to the extent that can be assured by design of the experiment.

Not until agreement among our group members that the analysis process is finally regarded as complete (based on various properties of the data, such as self-consistency measures and various uncertainty estimates, but excluding knowledge of the ISLV signal magnitude or sign), is the secret numerical key then inserted to reveal the quantitative conclusion.  That final result, the ISLV sign, magnitude and uncertainty, with no reconsideration, is then to be submitted for publication.  The stakes are high and our research group has been and remains highly motivated to achieve the highest overall precision that our experimental design allows.
